awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Practical Algorithms and Fundamental Limits for Complex Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Designing software that can properly and safely interact with the physical world is an important cyber-physical systems design challenge. The proposed work includes the development of a novel approach to designing planning and control algorithms for high-performance cyber physical systems. The new approach was inspired by statistical mechanics and stochastic geometry. It will (i) identify behavior such as phase transitions in cyber-physical systems and (ii) capitalize this behavior in order to design practical algorithms with provable correctness and performance guarantees. The algorithms developed through this research effort hold the potential for immediate industrial impact, particularly in the development of real-time robotic systems. These algorithms may strengthen the rapidly developing U.S. robotics industry. The proposed research activity will also vitalize the PI?s educational plans. Undergraduate
and graduate courses that make substantial contributions to the embedded systems education
at MIT will be developed. The classes will focus on provably-correct controller synthesis for cyber-physical systems, which is currently not thought at MIT. Undergraduate students will be involved in research activities.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a foundational understanding and applications for mobile robotic Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) where their sensors, actuators and computers can be co-designed. On the theoretical front, we studied problems that, for example, involve a vehicle visiting multiple points either to collect information or to execute a task. In this setting, we have developed a complete theory that characterizes the performance for almost all possible dynamical configurations and point distributions. On the applied front, we developed new methodologies for the co-design of computing hardware and algorithms for on-board efficient execution of complex autonomy tasks. We demonstrated our methodology on a novel design of a chip that computes the ego-motion of an optical-inertial sensor using a few miliWatts. We fabricated this chip on the 65 nanometer process node and demonstrated it on widely utilized data sets. Our work has shown that the new methodology enables orders of magnitude savings in energy consumption. 

 

In addition, the project developed a new pedagogy that inverts the laboratory and project experiences for students. Traditionally, the students work through a mechanical list of laboratory exercises on campus with the help of instructors. Near the end of the class, they do their projects outside the classroom without direct feedback from the instructors. We invert this experience with the help of new software and online communication tools. Specifically, we develop software that powers mini-scale take-home experiments on realistic platforms, such as a mini 1/10-scale electric car and a palm-size drone, and give them to the students for the entire semester. The students conduct the mechanical set of tasks in traditional laboratory exercises outside the classroom, but with the help of online videos, online forums, and new automated code grading software. They, then, develop their projects in the classroom in a hackathon style events where the instructors are present. This new pedagogy drastically improves the quality of the projects. The extensive hands-on component helps the students better understand the concepts by doing them in rigorous projects. 

 

Finally, the project helped develop new extensive outreach programs for high-school students and middle-school students. The new outreach program is a rigorous four-week program with hands-on exercises, the first version of which was built on the undergraduate courses mentioned above. The program has quickly grown out of the first offering under the direction of the MIT Lincoln Laboratory. In the last five years since its inception, this program has reached more than 1000 high-school and middle-school students in this four-week summer program; in addition, in weekend courses, it reached an additional 600 students who are from underrepresented backgrounds.
